In this study, Cu, Fe/SBA-15 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, and a series of characterization were carried out. XRD, physical adsorption and TEM results showed that SBA-15 molecular sieve has a highly ordered two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous structure, and the loading of active components does not significantly destroy the ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15. The catalyst with Cu: Fe=2:1 showed the best catalytic performance, and the oxidation yield of phenylcarbinol reached 54 % at 90 °C with DMSO as solvent and TBHP as oxidant for 3 h. Physical and chemical analysis by XPS, DR. UV–vis and H2-TPR showed that Cu-Fe synergistic effect can significantly improve the catalytic performance, the highly dispersed Cu species in bimetallic catalysts were more concentrated on the catalyst surface, which improved the redox performance and electron transfer ability of the catalysts. The above characterization results provide strong evidence to explain the difference of catalytic activity. Graphical abstract The yield of 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol is higher than that of Cu/SBA-15 and Fe/SBA-15, which is related to the surface dispersion of CuO and mainly determined by the interaction between Cu-Fe. Image, graphical abstract Keywords SBA-15 molecular sieve Cu-Fe synergistic effect Selective catalytic oxidation Phenylcarbinol Dispersion Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Benzaldehyde is an important chemical raw material, which is used in the fields of medicine and fragrance. The benzaldehyde produced by the traditional preparation method contains chlorine atom or chloride impurity, and there are problems such as low yield and environmental pollution, so its application is limited. The synthesis of benzaldehyde by direct oxidation of toluene has some problems such as low yield and poor selectivity [1,2]. Therefore, the more economical and green preparation method of benzaldehyde has attracted much attention [3–5]. Liquefaction oxidation of phenylcarbinol is an effective synthesis method with both environmental friendliness and high yield, but it is still in the research stage [6]. Catalysts, solvents, oxidants and other reaction conditions are the main factors affecting the yield and quality of benzaldehyde, among which the preparation of highly efficient catalysts is considered to be the key to achieve high yield. SBA-15 is widely used as catalyst support because of its highly ordered two-dimensional hexagonal structure, large specific surface area, unique microporous structure and high hydrothermal stability [7]. Moreover, the pore size can be adjusted when loaded by different materials. Loading Pt, Pd and other precious metals on SBA-15 can improve the structure and distribution of active components, and then improve its catalytic performance, but the price factor hinders its popularization and application [8,9]. In recent years, SBA-15 supported non-precious metal catalyst has attracted extensive interest, but its catalytic activity needs to be optimized. Therefore, the development of highly efficient and stable non-precious metal supported SBA-15 catalyst is of great significance for the realization of liquid-phase heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of benzaldehyde. How to improve the activity of metal-supported SBA-15 catalyst is the key to improve the yield of benzaldehyde from catalytic oxidation of phenylcarbinol. In recent years, bimetallic catalysts have become the focus of research in the field of catalysis because of their synergistic effects [10]. Yu prepared benzaldehyde by oxidation of copper-nickel composite catalysts and found that copper-nickel composite metal catalysts had better catalytic performance than the respective mono-metal catalysts [10]. Fan oxidized formaldehyde through iron-cerium composite catalyst and found that iron content and calcination temperature had a great influence on the generation of oxygen vacancy in the catalyst, and thus affected its catalytic performance [11]. The bimetallic system composed of Cu and Fe has a good prospect of heterogeneous catalytic reaction [12]. Cu-based catalysts are widely used because of their low price and high catalytic activity, while Fe is an important catalyst and auxiliary agent, which can effectively improve the oxidation capacity of catalysts [13–15]. Wu prepared phenol by oxidation of copper-iron composite catalyst and found that copper can effectively prevent the oxidation of iron to benzene, improve the selectivity of phenol and control the reaction process [16]. Therefore, in this study, the commonly used non-precious metal elements Cu and Fe are selected as the active components, and the effects of different Cu and Fe species and reaction conditions on the catalytic oxidation of phenylcarbinol are studied through the design of materials and preparation methods, and the effects of Cu-Fe synergism on the active species, redox properties, material structure and catalytic activity are investigated. In this study, the second active components of Fe, Mn, Ni and Co were added to Cu/SBA-15 to determine the optimal combination and synergy, and the results showed that Cu-Fe had the best synergy and the corresponding catalyst showed the highest yield (As shown in Fig. S1). Therefore, this study focuses on the synergistic effect of Cu-Fe. To clarify the synergic mechanism, species status and structural properties of the active components Cu-Fe, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR and other characterization methods were used in this study. Experimental Catalyst preparation In this experiment, Cu-Fe/SBA-15 bimetallic catalyst was prepared by excessive impregnation method with Cu as the reactive center to study the interaction between Cu and Fe [17–19]. The specific synthetic steps were as follows. SBA-15 powder (0.2 g) were weighed and dissolved in n-hexane, an appropriate amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were dissolved in a certain amount of anhydrous ethanol to form suspension. The suspension is stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h and left for 3 h, and then dried by the rotary evaporation at 70 °C in vacuum. The obtained catalyst precursor was calcined in Muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the bimetallic catalyst. When the Cu+Fe mass percentage of the catalyst is 10 %, the obtained catalyst is named as xCu:yFe/SBA-15 (x:y represents the molar ratio of Cu to Fe). If the Cu+Fe mass percentage of the catalyst is 20 %, the obtained catalyst is named as xCu:yFe-20/SBA-15 (x:y represents the molar ratio of Cu to Fe). The obtained catalysts information and abbreviations are shown in Table 1 . Activity measurement Clean sealed tubes were loaded with agitator, 0.01 g supported catalyst (Cu:Fe/SBA-15), 0.26 g phenylcarbinol (2.5 mmol), solvent DMSO (2.00 mL) and oxidizer TBHP (0.30 mL) [20,21]. After sealing, the reaction was vigorously stirred in a water bath at 90 °C for 3 h, and then treated with a filter. The composition of the reactants and products in the purified liquid was analyzed by GC–MS, and the relevant results were calculated according to the obtained peak area. (To facilitate the calculation, the peak area of different species was corrected by external standard method). The catalytic performance was expressed in terms of Benzaldehyde yield (Eq. (1)), Phenylcarbinol conversion (Eq. (2)) and Benzaldehyde selectivity (Eq. (3)): (1) yield ( % ) = benzaldehyde peak area total peak area × 100 (2) conversion ( % ) = total peak atea − phenylcarbinol peak area total peak atea × 100 (3) selectivity ( % ) = benzaldehyde peak area total peak area − phenylcarbinol peak area × 100 Catalyst characterizations GC–MS (Agilent 6890 N/5975MSD, America), using adsorbents to separate the adsorption force of each component and the different running speed, to obtain the peak area of each component, sensitivity: 1pgOFN, m/z: 272, S/N: 175:1. XRD (Empyrean, Netherlands) uses Cu-Kα radiation source (wavelength λ=0.15418 nm) for small angle 0.5°−5° and wide angle 15°−75° scanning at a scanning speed of 6°·min−1. The XRD patterns obtained are compared with JCPDS cards to obtain the crystal structure and phase information of the catalyst. N2 Physisorption (N2 Physisorption, America) according to BET (Bruner-Emmett-Teller), t-plot, Theoretical model formulas such as BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) calculate the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the material. SEM (JSM-6360LV, Japan), equipped with anOxford X-act energy dispersive X-ray (EDS) spectrometer, is used to determine the morphology of the catalyst under the conditions of 30 kV acceleration voltage, 3.0 nm resolution. TEM (JEM-1011, Japan) is used to determine the morphology of the catalyst at an acceleration voltage of 100 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha using the Al-Kα line (hv=1486.6 eV), Charge correction was carried out based on the binding energy of contaminated carbon C1s (284.80 eV) of the bulk. The measured XPS map was fitted with XPSPEAK41 sub-peak software. H2-TPR (Micromeritics AutoChem 2920, America) was used to take 50 mg of the sample, and the sample was heated up at 10 °C·min−1 to 300 °C for 30 min under He atmosphere for pre-treatment. He atmosphere was protected and dropped to room temperature and stabilized for 10 min. Then, the reduction gas composed of 10 % H2-Ar was introduced, and the heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 was increased from room temperature to 800 °C, and the gas flow rate was 50 mL·min−1. The H2 consumption in the tail gas was detected by the thermal conductivity detection tank (TCD). According to the calibration curve of TCD signal intensity and H2 concentration, the change of H2 concentration with temperature was determined, and then the hydrogen consumption was calculated during the programmed heating process. Results Catalytic activities In this study, Cu-Fe bimetallic catalyst is selected as the research object to achieve a double breakthrough in catalytic performance and reaction mechanism. The Cu/Fe ratio was compared under the same reaction conditions. The results of GC–MS, as shown in Table S2, showed that the main oxidation product of the reaction is benzaldehyde, and the by-product is mainly benzoic acid. And the relevant calculation results are shown in Table 2 . It can be seen from the results that the yield and selectivity of the bimetal catalyst are higher than that of the single metal catalyst, and the addition of appropriate amount of Fe can improve the activity of the Cu-based catalyst. Among them, 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 showed the best catalytic performance with a yield of 53.97 %. The stability of the catalyst was evaluated. It can be seen from Table S3 that the catalytic performance of the catalyst didn't decrease significantly after repeated use. The results also show that the recovery of catalyst is very good. The spent catalyst was also characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and XRF (As shown in Table S4), and it was found that the structure and composition of the catalyst didn't change significantly, indicating that the stability of the catalyst was good. Reaction conditions: 0.01 g catalyst, 0.26 g phenylcarbinol, solvent DMSO (2.00 mL) and oxidizer TBHP (0.30 mL), the reaction was vigorously stirred in a water bath at 90 °C for 3 h Analysis of catalyst structure characteristics XRD analysis of catalyst In this experiment, SBA-15 is used as a support. Fig. 1 shows the comparison of the crystal structure of the catalyst supported by SBA-15 with Cu and Fe. Small angle diffraction peaks of Cu and Fe/SBA-15 catalysts still exist after Cu and Fe loading compared with SBA-15 (as shown in Fig. 1(a)), indicating that the catalysts loaded with Cu and Fe still retain the basic characteristics of mesoporous molecular sieves with hexagonal symmetry. It is found that the intensity of diffraction peaks is significantly weakened after metal loading, indicating that the long-range order of the sample is reduced to a certain extent, which may be related to Cu and Fe entering the molecular sieve pore or skeleton. At the same time, the diffraction peak shifts towards higher angle (0.84°→0.88°), which can also indicate that CuO and Fe2O3 successfully enters the pore channel of SBA-15 molecular sieve, reducing the pore size of the molecular sieve [22]. As shown in Fig. 1(b) of wide-angle XRD, the characteristic peaks of CuO and Fe2O3 appear between 30°and 75° The characteristic peak of CuO in pure Cu-catalyst is significantly higher than that of Fe2O3 in pure Fe-catalyst, indicating that the crystallinity of Fe is much lower than that of Cu [23]. When Fe coexists with Cu, Fe can effectively inhibit the aggregation of Cu species (93.5 nm→81.1 nm) and improve the crystallinity of Cu species on SBA-15, which may be indirectly related to the dispersion of Cu species and also affect the catalytic performance of Cu-Fe/SBA-15 [24]. Analysis of physical adsorption results of catalyst The N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curves of the support SBA-15 molecular sieve and the catalyst are showed in Fig. 2 (a). The curves both show type-IV N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curves, which are typical mesoporous materials [25]. Impregnation of Cu or Fe to the support SBA-15 molecular sieve do not change the type of N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curve, but the total N2 adsorption capacity decreased, and the reduction of N2 adsorption capacity of each catalytic material is 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 and Fe/SBA-15 in order from large to small. It shows that some pores of the molecular sieve are occupied by oxide particles [26]. Fig 2(b) shows the pore size distribution curve of the sample. The pore diameter distribution of the pure SBA-15 molecular sieve is relatively concentrated (about 6.3 nm-9.3 nm), while the pore diameter distribution of the catalyst becomes broader (about 3.7 nm-25.5 nm). This may be related to the accumulation of oxide pores and the blockage of molecular sieve pores. According to the N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curves of the support molecular sieve and catalyst in Fig. 2, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of each sample can be calculated (as shown in Table 3 ). The specific surface area and pore volume decreases after Cu and Fe are loaded on the support molecular sieve. This is related to the fact that Cu and Fe ions enter the pore of SBA-15 molecular sieve support and occupy the pore space volume. The single metal catalyst has a greater effect on the molecular sieve support, which may be related to the relatively poor dispersion of pure Cu and Fe, which is more likely to destroy the molecular sieve skeleton structure. The decline range of the specific surface area of 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 catalyst is smaller than Cu/SBA-15 and Fe/SBA-15 catalyst, which may be related to the synergistic effect of Cu-Fe to improve the dispersion of the active component. Analysis of catalyst SEM results Fig. 3 shows the SEM image of 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 catalyst, the particle morphology of the catalyst is similar to that of pure SBA-15 mesoporous molecular sieve, and clear pore structure can still be observed after amplification, indicating that the structure is not damaged after loading, and still maintains a good order. However, after careful comparison of the molecular sieve support, it is found that the long-range order degree decreased to a certain extent, and the curvature increased. Fig. 4 shows the EDS spectra of each sample. Cu and Fe are evenly distributed on the surface of SBA-15, and the addition of Fe can enhance the dispersion and stability of Cu (as shown in Fig. 4(b)), and the uniform dispersion of species on the surface is conducive to the full contact and interaction between the active components of the catalyst, so as to achieve the purpose of improving catalytic activity. The content of Cu in mesoporous channels is greater than that of Fe, indicating that CuO is more likely to enter the pore structure than Fe2O3. Table 4 shows the mass ratio of elements on the surface of each sample measured by EDS, which shows that surface Cu:Fe≈1:1 in 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15. The reason may be that because the radius of Cu ions is smaller than that of Fe ions, and Cu species are more likely to enter the molecular sieve channels, resulting in a decrease in the surface concentration of Cu objects. However, compared with Cu/SBA-15 catalyst, the Cu:Si on the surface increased slightly (0.019→0.079). It is speculated that this may be related to the synergistic effect of Cu-Fe, which increases the concentration of Cu species in the 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 surface catalyst. TEM analysis of catalyst SBA-15, 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15, Fe/SBA-15, Cu/SBA-15 all show similar morphologies in Fig. 5 . The pore diameter of SBA-15 is about 7.02 nm, with regular parallel hexagonal pore structure and uniform pore diameter distribution, which is consistent with the N2 adsorption-desorption curve and XRD characterization results. After metal loading, the pore diameter decreases from 7.02 nm to 5.85 nm (2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15), 6.28 nm (Cu/SBA-15) and 6.4 nm (Fe/SBA-15), which proves that the addition of metal fills the mesoporous channels of SBA-15. The pore diameter is reduced and the pore wall is thickened, which may be conducive to the enhancement of the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. The long-range ordered structure of the catalyst channels shows that the addition of metals does not destroy the structural characteristics of SBA-15, which may also be a factor to ensure the catalytic performance of the material [27]. Analysis of catalyst XPS results In order to determine the valence and concentration of elements on the catalyst surface, XPS characterization was performed. The result of Gaussian function fitting is shown in Fig. 6 . In the XPS spectrum of Cu 2p (as can be seen from Fig. 6(a)), the double peaks at the positions of 932.6 eV and 952.6 eV can be attributed to CuO. In addition, two satellite peaks at 942.6 ± 0.1 eV and 961.0 ± 0.1 eV further demonstrate the presence of CuO on the surface [28]. Due to the different electronic structure of Cu2+ (3d9) and Cu+ (3d10) ions, Cu+ has no electronic transition and does not show satellite peaks in the spectrum [29,30]. Compared with Cu/SBA-15, the surface CuO content of 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 is higher, which may be due to the synergistic effect between Cu-Fe and the addition of Fe increases the concentration of CuO on the surface of the support, which is consistent with the activity results [31]. It can be seen from Fig. 6(b) that the 2p3/2 of Fe in the sample can be divided into three sub-peaks after fitting, corresponding to FeⅡ Octa, FeⅢ Octa and FeⅢ Tetra, and their binding energies are 709.8 eV, 711.4 eV and 713.1 eV, respectively. The peaks of 709.8 eV and 711.4 eV belong to Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions at the spinel Fe3O4 octahedral position, respectively, while the peaks of 713.1 eV belong to Fe3+ at the tetrahedral position. It is generally believed that the oxidation mechanism of alcohols is the oxidation of high-priced metal complexes into corresponding carbonyl compounds. Under the condition of Fe(Ⅲ)/TBHP, the oxidation path of alcohols is thought to be through the formation of a high-priced Fe species (VFe=O), and then reaction with hydroxyl group to form carbonyl compounds, accompanied by the reduction of Fe(Ⅲ) [32]. The O 1 s orbits of the three catalysts can be fitted into one XPS subpeak, as shown in Fig. 6(c). Oα’ with a binding energy of 533.7 ± 0.3 eV is classified as surface Si-O. Analysis of catalyst H2-TPR results The oxidation-reducing property of the catalyst plays a very important role in the catalytic performance. The distribution of the catalyst synthesized by impregnation method on H2-TPR is shown in Fig. 7 . Fe/SBA-15 catalyst showed three reduction peaks, the first peak at 332 °C, mainly attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4; The second peak is located at 522 ℃, mainly attributed to the reduction of Fe3O4→FeO. The third peak is located at 652 °C, which is mainly attributed to partial reduction of FeO→Fe [33,32]. Cu/SBA-15 catalyst shows three main reduction peaks, and the peak at 380 °C is attributed to the reduction of large particle polymerization CuO. The peak at 540 °C is attributed to the reduction of Cu ions entering the skeleton (which is difficult to reduce in the inert mesoporous silica), and the H2 consumption is less due to the small number of Cu species entering the skeleton. The last peak at 642 °C is related to Cu++1/2H2→Cu0+H +, which is mainly derived from the existing Cu+ in the sample. Compared with Cu/SBA-15, Fe/SBA-15, xCu:yFe/SBA-15 have a new low temperature reduction peak located at 230–260 °C. According to literature reports, this peak can be attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO, which indicates that Fe species can promote the dispersion of CuO on the surface, and therefore also proves the synergistic effect between Cu and Fe [34]. In addition, the electronic interaction between Cu and Fe can also promote the reduction of Cu species [34]. As the proportion of Fe species decreases, so does the amount of highly dispersed CuO. According to literature reports, surface highly dispersed CuO is the main active center of catalytic oxidation reaction, and finely dispersed CuO is easy to be reduced [35]. With the increase of Cu content, the hydrogen consumption decreases, indicating that the increase of Cu content causes the accumulation of CuO, which reduces the surface highly dispersed CuO and weakens the oxidation performance. The second peak of xCu:yFe/SBA-15 is located at 310–330 °C, which is mainly attributed to Fe2O3→Fe3O4, and the hydrogen consumption increases with the increase of Cu proportion. The third peak is located between 340 and 370 °C, which can be attributed to high-poly large particle CuO. Due to the synergistic effect of Cu and Fe, hydrogen consumption decreases first and then increases with the increase of Cu content. Polymerized Cu oxide is not an active component, so it is not conducive to the selective oxidation of phenylcarbinol. The last two reduction peaks can be classified as FeO (Fe3O4→FeO) and Fe, Cu+ (FeO→Fe, Cu+→Cu0), respectively. Since the fifth reduction peak contains and is dominated by the reduction of Cu+, its hydrogen consumption is greater than that of the fourth reduction peak. According to the above phenomena, the catalyst activity is the strongest when the ratio of Cu to Fe is 1:1, but because the oxidation of phenylcarbinol is selective oxidation, too high oxidation activity will lead to the formation of by-products, so Cu:Fe=2:1 is the best metal ratio condition. Discussion Combined with XRD and physical adsorption results, it can be seen that the synergistic effect between Cu and Fe can significantly inhibit the aggregation of Cu and Fe species and their damage to the structure of SBA-15 molecular sieve. Compared to pure Cu/SBA-15, the introduction of Fe not only can prevent the agglomeration of CuO particles, but also can improve the BET surface area from 398.1 to 405.6 m2·g − 1, which also contributed to higher catalytic activity towards the selective oxidation of phenylcarbinol. The results of EDS and XPS analysis showed that more Cu species in the single Cu catalyst entered the molecular sieve, and the surface concentration of Cu/SBA-15 catalyst was relatively low. The situation is completely opposite for the single Fe catalyst, Fe species are mainly concentrated on the surface of molecular sieve. This is mainly due to the fact that the radius of Fe3+ in the liquid phase is more than that of Cu2+, and it is difficult to enter the molecular sieve [36]. For Cu-Fe bimetallic catalysts, the concentration of Cu species on the molecular sieve surface increases, while the concentration of Fe decreases, which may be related to the synergistic interaction of Cu-Fe and the formation of Cu-Fe composite oxides between the two, the details of which will be discussed in depth below [37]. According to the literatures [38–40] and the above characterization results, the evolution of Cu distribution and state during Fe addition is proposed, and the synergistic interaction of Cu-Fe and their effects on molecular sieve are also concerned. As shown in Fig. 8 , compared with single metal catalyst, the Cu-Fe synergistic effect in bimetal catalyst is conducive to the formation of CuFeO x composite oxide between the two metals, and the solute drag effect of the composite oxide can effectively inhibit the agglomeration and particle growth of the two metal oxides, thus improving the dispersion of the active species [41]. Meanwhile, the compound between Cu-Fe will also lead to the increase of Cu species remaining on the surface of the molecular sieve, and the same reason that the Fe entering the molecular sieve will also increase. Therefore, the excellent catalytic performance of 2Cu:1Fe/SBA-15 is mainly related to the synergistic effect of Fe3+/Fe2+ and Cu2+/Cu+ redox cycles and the high dispersion of Cu species. In this paper, the mechanism of the catalytic reaction is also preliminarily proposed (As shown in Fig. 9 ) [42], and more detailed discussion and characterization will be supplemented in subsequent studies. Conclusion In this study, physical adsorption, TEM and other characterization methods are used to analyze the structural characteristics of the supported catalyst. After metal loading, SBA-15 can still maintain a good two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous structure, and Fe can effectively inhibit the aggregation of Cu species, enhance its dispersion effect, and enhance its catalytic activity. Secondly, XPS, H2-TPR and other characterization methods were used to analyze the redox ability of the catalyst from the perspective of electron transfer, and it is concluded that the surface highly dispersed CuO is the main active center of catalytic oxidation. Due to the synergistic effect between Cu-Fe, the concentration of surface highly dispersed CuO and the synergistic redox cycles can be improved, thus achieving the improvement of catalytic activity. The correctness of the optimal molar ratio Cu:Fe=2:1 is further verified from the microscopic point of view (Table 5 ,Table 6 ). coredata.dc:description: In this study, Cu, Fe/SBA-15 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, and a series of characterization were carried out. XRD, physical adsorption and TEM results showed that SBA-15 molecular sieve has a highly ordered two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous structure, and the loading of active components does not significantly destroy the ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15. The catalyst with Cu: Fe=2:1 showed the best catalytic performance, and the oxidation yield of phenylcarbinol reached 54 % at 90 °C with DMSO as solvent and TBHP as oxidant for 3 h. Physical and chemical analysis by XPS, DR. UV–vis and H2-TPR showed that Cu-Fe synergistic effect can significantly improve the catalytic performance, the highly dispersed Cu species in bimetallic catalysts were more concentrated on the catalyst surface, which improved the redox performance and electron transfer ability of the catalysts. The above characterization results provide strong evidence to explain the difference of catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Selective catalytic oxidation of phenylcarbinol with Fe-doped Cu/SBA-15 catalyst: A study on the synergistic effect of Cu-Fe metals
